Twenty-two minutes by the kitchen clock.  Not a word, not a motion. What am I thinking? "My arm's getting tired?" No.  I did it.  I did it.  Like in the old says, Ricky.  Like I was taught... turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Oh, and I don't get a moment to spare for a bust-out humanitarian down on his luck lately.  Fuck you, Dave, you know you got a big mouth, and you make a close the whole place stinks with your farts for a week. "How much you just ingested," what a big man you are, "Hey, let me buy you a pack of gum.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: I'll show you how to chew it." Your pal closes, all that comes out of your mouth is bile, how fucked up you are...

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: Who's my pal...?  And what are you, Ricky, huh, what are you, Bishop Sheean?  Who the fuck are you, Mr. Slick...?  What are you, friend to the workingman?  Big deal.  Fuck you, you got the memory a fuckin' fly.  I never liked you.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: What is this, your farewell speech?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: I'm going home.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Your farewell to the troops?

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: I'm not going home.  I'm going to Wisconsin.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Have a good trip.

turns.speaker: MOSS
turns.text: And fuck you.  Fuck the lot of you. Fuck you all.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: They didn't get your contract.  I filed it before I left.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: They didn't get my contracts.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: They--excuse me...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: They didn't get the contracts.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Did they...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: They got, listen to me...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: The...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Listen to me: They got some of them.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Some of them...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: They took some of the con...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: ...some of the contracts...Lingk. James Lingk.  I closed...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: You closed him yesterday.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: It went down.  I filed it.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: You did?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Then I'm over the fucking top and you owe me a Cadillac.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: To the restaura...what do you fucking...?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Aren't you going out today?

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: With what?  With what, John, they took the leads...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: I have the stuff from last year's...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Oh.  Oh.  Oh, your "nostalgia" file, they's fine.  No.  Swell. 'Cause I don't have to...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: ...you want to go out today...?

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: 'Cause I don't have to eat this month.  No.  Okay.  Give 'em to me...  Fucking Mitch and Murray going to shit a br...what am I going to do all...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Patel?  Ravidam Patel?  How am I going to make a living on thses deadbeat wogs?  Where did you get this, from the morgue?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: If you don't want it, give it back.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: I don't "want" it, if you catch my drift.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: I'm giving you three leads.  You...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: What's the fucking point in any case...?  What's the point.  I got to argue with you, I got to knock heads with the cops, I'm busting my balls, sell you dirt to fucking deadbeats money in the mattress, I come back you can't even manage to keep the contracts safe, I have to go back and close them again...What the fuck am I wasting my time, fuck this shit.  I'm going out and reclose last week's...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: The word from Murray is: leave them alone.  If we need a new signature he'll go out himself, he'll be the president, just come in, from out of town...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Okay, okay, okay, gimme this shit. Fine.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Three?  I count two.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Three.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Patel?  Fuck you.  Fuckin' Shiva handed him a million dollars, told him "sign the deal," he wouldn't sign.  And Vishnu, too.  Into the bargain.  Fuck that, John.  You know your business, I know mine. Your business is being an asshole, and I find out whose fucking cousin you are, I'm going to go to him and figure out a way to have your ass... fuck you--I'll wait for the new leads.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Mr. Lingk and I are going to...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Yes.  Please.  Please.  The police  can be...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: We had a slight burglary last night.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: It was nothing...I was assuring Mr. Lingk...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Mr. Lingk.  James Lingk.  Your contract went out.  Nothing to...

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: John...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Your contract went out to the bank.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: ...Mr. Williamson...

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: Your check as cashed yesterday afternoon.  And we're completely insured, as you know, in any case.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMSON
turns.text: ...I wouldn't worry about it.

turns.speaker: ROMA
turns.text: Well I'm going to worry about it, and so are you, so shut up and listen.  I GET HIS ACTION.  My stuff is mine, whatever he gets for himself, I'm talking half.  You put me in with him.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Are you alright?

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Did you like your party?

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: I got lots of presents.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Do you like them?

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: I didn't know the people who gave them to me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: They were friends.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: Did you see my present for you?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, where is it?

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: On your pillow.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm leaving very early tomorrow, before you wake up.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: I know.  How long will you be gone?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Just a few days.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: Will you take me?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: Why do you have to go?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: To do business.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: I can help you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Some day you will.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You've grown so tall... so tall in the last year.  You're much taller than me.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: I was taller than you when I was fourteen.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Sit down.  Your Aunt Connie and I waited for you to have some lunch, but now it's all dried out.

turns.speaker: ANTHONY
turns.text: I'm not hungry.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Well, that's alright... alright. Good.  You'll graduate in another year, isn't that right?  You know... I never finished college.  I was a good student, but I never finished. Of course, there was a war then.

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Mr. Cicci.  From the year 1927 to the present time, you were an employee of the "Genco Olive Oil Company."

turns.speaker: CICCI
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: But in actuality, you were a member of the Corleone Crime organization.

turns.speaker: CICCI
turns.text: The Corleone Family, Senator.  We called it, "The Family."

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: What position did you occupy?

turns.speaker: CICCI
turns.text: At first, like everybody, I was a soldier.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: I have a friend who has a fine rug. Maybe your wife would like it.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: We have no money for a rug.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: No.  He would give it away.  I know how to repay a consideration.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: Your friend lives in a fine building.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Oh yes, the very best.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: They say Fanucci has a license from Maranzalla himself to work this neighborhood.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: If you like, why not give me fifty dollars each to pay Fanucci.  I guarantee he will accept that amount from me.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: Fanucci is not connected; he is alone.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: What?  You read it in the papers?

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: This man informs to the police; this man allows his vengeance to be bought off... No, he is alone.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: Who is the greatest man you can think of?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Go on, answer him when he talks to you.  Tell him: Columbus, Marconi... Garibaldi.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: What took so long?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: She couldn't decide.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: Do you think he'd be satisfied with the two hundred dollars?  I think he would.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: That scar-faced bastard will find out what we got from the wholesaler. He won't take a dime less than three hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: What if we don't pay?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: You know his friends...real animals. And his connections with the police. Sure he'd like us to tell him our plans so he can set us up for the cops and earn their gratitude. Then they would owe him a favor; that's how he operates.  We'll have to pay.  Three hundred, are we agreed?

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: What can we do?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Vitone!  Our driver has drunk too much wine.

turns.speaker: TESSIO
turns.text: He's going to kill Fanucci.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Then, after that, what?  Joe 'Little Knife' Pisani; Willie Bufalino, maybe, Mr. Maranzalla himself, c'mon!

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Constanzia.  We expected you last week; we sent the car to pick you up at the airport last week.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: I know, it was chaos; but anyway, here I am one week late.  This is for my Mama.  You remember Merle?

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Yes, thank you.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: How are the kids?

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Well, thank you, they asked for you all week.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: I got surprises for everybody!

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Bought at the airport.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: This is swell.  Where's Michael? I've got things to get straight with him and I can't wait on line.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: You go see your children first, and then you wait to see your brother like everybody else.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: It means we should all live happily for one hundred years.  The family. If my Father were alive, it'd be true.

turns.speaker: MAMA
turns.text: Connie.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Merle, have you met my sister-in- law Deanna?

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: How are you, honey?  You've met Merle, haven't you.  He was with me in Vegas.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I saw him with you.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: We're going to Europe next week.  I want to get passage booked on the Queen.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Why do you come to me?  Why don't you go to a travel agent?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The ink on your divorce isn't dry. Your children see you on weekends; your oldest boy, Michael Francis... was in some trouble with the Reno police over some petty theft that you don't even know about.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Michael...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You fly around the world with lazy young men who don't have any love for you, and use you like a whore.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: You're not my father!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then why do you come to me?

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Because I need MONEY!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Connie, I want to be reasonable with you.  You have a house here, with us.  You can live here with your kids...and you won't be deprived of anything.  I don't know much about Merle; I don't know what he does for a living; what he lives on.  Why don't you tell him marriage is really out of the question; and that you can't see him any more. He'll understand.  But if you disobey me, and marry this pimp...it would disappoint me.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: It was my father's money; and I'm entitled to what I need.  Where is Tom Hagen?

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Is Kay coming?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Michael, Fredo's in the house with Mama.  He asked for you, and Tom said he couldn't see you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Tom is right.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Kids, why don't you go outside for a while?

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: I want to talk to you, Michael.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The children can stay.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: I hated you for so long, Michael; for so many years.  I think I did things to myself, to hurt myself, so that you would know -- and you would be hurt too.  But I understand you now; I think I do.  You were being strong for all of us, like Papa was.  And I forgive you, and want to be close to you now.  Can't you forgive Fredo; he's so sweet, and helpless without you.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Honey!  Wait a minute; let's go for a drive.

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: I just had a drive; besides, I want to see my brother-in-law Michael.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Yeah, but I don't want him to see you.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Goddamn bitch.

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: Relax, Freddie honey.  Come dance with me.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Listen, Michael's got a lot of nice people here.  Friends of Kay's. He'll never forgive me if you ruin his party.

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: I hate to see you cringe in front of him.  How come you're so scared of your own kid brother?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: He's the head of the family.

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: What's 'cent' Anne?'

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: A hundred years...it's a toast.

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: I wanta dance...whatsa matter with that?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Dancing is alright; you're falling on the floor.

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: Whatsamatter, you don't want me to dance with him 'cause he's a man!

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Deanna, I'm going to belt you right in the mouth!

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: These Eye-ties are really crazy when it comes to their wives.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Deanna, will you get back into the house!

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: I'm getting out of here I said; these guys all have guns!

turns.speaker: DEANNA
turns.text: I don't want to stay here...

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Mike, what can I do, she's a hysterical woman...

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Would you like some?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, Dad.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Now what is this talk about joining the army?  Eh?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It's not talk; I'm doing it.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: You would risk your life for strangers?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Not for strangers; for my country.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Anyone not in your family, is a stranger.  Believe me, when trouble comes, your country won't take care of you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: That's how it was in the old world, Pop, but this is not Sicily.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I know.  I know, Michael.  It's Christmas, your brothers and sister are all here -- we are happy. Let's not spoil this.  Go your own way, but when you are ready, come to me the way a son should.  I have hopes for you...

turns.speaker: WIDOW
turns.text: Don Francesco.  You murdered my husband, because he would not bend. And his oldest son Paolo, because he swore revenge.  But Vitone is only nine, and dumb-witted.  He never speaks.

turns.speaker: DON FRANCESCO
turns.text: I'm not afraid of his words.

turns.speaker: WIDOW
turns.text: He is weak.

turns.speaker: DON FRANCESCO
turns.text: He will grow strong.

turns.speaker: WIDOW
turns.text: The child cannot harm you.

turns.speaker: DON FRANCESCO
turns.text: He will be a man, and then he will come for revenge.

turns.speaker: FANUCCI
turns.text: Otherwise the police will come to see you and your wife and children will be dishonored and destitute. Of course, if my information as to your gains is incorrect, I'll dip my beak just a little.  Just a little, but no less than one hundred dollars, and don't try to deceive me, eh paisan?

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: My two friends have my share of the money.  I'll have to speak to them after we deliver these to the wholesaler.

turns.speaker: FANUCCI
turns.text: You tell your friends I expect them to let me wet my beak in the same manner.  Don't be afraid to tell them.  Clemenza and I know each other well, he understands these things.  Let yourself be guided by him.  He has more experience in these matters.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: You must understand, this is all new to me...

turns.speaker: FANUCCI
turns.text: I understand...

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: But thank you for speaking to me as a Godfather.

turns.speaker: FANUCCI
turns.text: You're a good fellow.

turns.speaker: FANUCCI
turns.text: I think there's only two hundred dollars under my hat.  I'm right.  Only two hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: VITO
turns.text: I'm a little short.  I've been out of work.  Let me owe you the money for a few weeks.

turns.speaker: FANUCCI
turns.text: Ah, you're a sharp young fellow. How is it I've never noticed you before  You're too quiet for your own interest.  I could find some work for you to do that would be very profitable.  No hard feelings, eh?  If I can ever do you a service let me know. You've done a good job for yourself tonight.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: Ten to one shot, you said.  Ten to one shot in my favor, and I lose.

turns.speaker: FBI MAN #1
turns.text: Get a good night's sleep.  We got a new suit, new shirt, new tie, and I'm going to shave you myself. Tomorrow we want you to look respectable for fifty million of your fellow Americans.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: My life won't be worth a nickel after tomorrow.

turns.speaker: FBI MAN #1
turns.text: We have a special home for you for the rest of your life.  Nobody gets near you.  You're not going any place.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: Yeah, some deal I made.

turns.speaker: FBI MAN #1
turns.text: Why'd you do it, Frankie?  After all these years, why'd you turn against him?

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: I didn't turn against nobody; he turned against me.

turns.speaker: FBI MAN #1
turns.text: Ready, Frankie.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Who's that?  Pentangeli?  Frankie "Five-Angels"...thought you were never coming West.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: Gotta check up on my boys.  Hey, what's with the food?  Some kid in a white jacket brings me a ritz cracker with some chopped liver. 'Canapes,' he says.  I say, 'Can a peas, my ass, that's a ritz cracker with chopped liver.' Go get me a salami sandwich and a glass of wine or I'll send you and your white jacket to the dry cleaners!

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Gee, Frankie, it's good to see you. Reminds me of old times.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: You remember Willy Cicci, don't you, Freddie?  We was all together with the old man Clemenza in Brooklyn... before...uh...

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: We were all upset about that.

turns.speaker: PENTANGELI
turns.text: That's what I'm here to talk to your brother about.  What's with him, I got to get a letter of introduction to have a 'sitdown'?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: C'mon, I see what I can do.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Hey Mike, what can I say?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Forget it, just go take care of her.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Hiya, Freddie Corleone.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Mio fratello.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Oh, 'scuse me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It's all right.  He stays with me all the time.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Oh.  Mikey, what's up?  I'm totally in the dark.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: We're making an investment in Havana.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Great, Havana's great.  Lots of activity in Havana!  Anybody I know here.  Five-Angels?  Anybody?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Johnny Ola... Hyman Roth.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: I never met them.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Pentangeli's dead.  He was ambushed by the Rosato Brothers.  Didn't you know that?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: No.  No, I didn't.  Who tells me anything?  I been kept in the dark so long, I'm getting used to it.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I want you to help me, Fredo.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: That's what I'm here for.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Tonight I want to relax with you. The Senator from Nevada is here with some people from Washington. I want to show them a good time in Havana.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Count on me; that's my specialty.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'd like to come along.  There's been a lot of strain, and I've been cooped up in this room for three days.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Me and you, great!  Gimme an hour to wash my face and do my research and we'll have these Washington suckers right where you want 'em.  Poor Frankie Five-Angels.  He always wanted to die in bed...with a broad.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Jeeze, it's great you came along, Mike... You know, we've never spent a night out on the town together. I always thought you looked down on me for liking a good time.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I never looked down on you, Fredo. You don't look down at a brother.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Mike, I got something special up my sleeve for these boys.  You ever hear of "Superman?" And I don't mean the comic book.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Wait'll you see!

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Mikey, why would they ever hit poor old Frankie Five-Angels?  I loved that ole sonuvabitch.  I remember when he was just a 'button,' when we were kids.  We used to put bedsheets on our heads, you know, like we were ghosts.  An' ole Frankie come peek into our room, we'd jump up, and he'd always pretend like he was really scared. You remember?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It was hard to have him killed.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: You?  What do you mean you, I thought...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It was hard to have him killed.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: You?  What do you mean you, I thought...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: It was Frankie tried to have me hit.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: No.  I mean, are you sure?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You know otherwise, Freddie?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Me?  NO, no, I don't know anything. Fellas!  You're all falling asleep. We got to see Superman.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How is your wife, Fredo...your marriage?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: You know her; drives me crazy, one minute she's a popsicle, the next she's all vinegar.  Sometimes I think... I think - I should a married someone, like you did.  To have kids, to have a family.
